entry.title: Chinchilla Updates
entry.summary: Several days ago, I was very shocked to find that Meredith the chinnie had passed away. She was Ellisâ€™s sisterâ€”our chinchilla with congestive heart failureâ€”and a bonded companion to Lexi.
entry.content:
Several days ago, I was very shocked to find that Meredith the chinnie had passed away. She was Ellisâ€™s sisterâ€”our chinchilla with congestive heart failureâ€”and a bonded companion to Lexi.

I spoke with our vet, and he explained that Meredith may have also had heart disease, even without showing symptoms. Sadly, heart disease is becoming much more common in chinchillasâ€”so much so that our vet now does chest X-rays before any surgery to make sure their hearts are strong enough for anesthesia.

People often asked me how I could tell Ellis and Meredith apart, and for me, it was easy: Meredith had more freckles on her ears, and she was always just a bit more human-friendly.

Of course, I would never try to replace Meredithâ€”or any animal that passes under my careâ€”but yesterday we received a message about a single female chinchilla in need. Thanks to quick action from one of our rescue friends and Jen, this girl will be coming to us on Sunday with a group of piggies.

Iâ€™m doing this mostly for Lexi.

Ellis could pass away at any time, and I donâ€™t want to be scrambling to find a companion for Lexi in the middle of grief. My hope is to bond them as a trio, so Lexi wonâ€™t be left alone when the time comes.

This is one of the hardest parts of rescue. Sometimes, even when your human heart isnâ€™t ready, you have to put the emotional needs of herd animals firstâ€”because they donâ€™t understand loss the way we do. But they feel it all the same.
